page.title: 03Steeple and Middle Barton
page.content: Western area: Steeple Barton, near St. Mary's Church, was a thriving community from about the year 800 providing food for the royal court at Woodstock and then for Oseney Abbey in Oxford. This ended about 1350 with the Black Death and the centre of activity moved to Middle Barton. For many years Steeple Barton did not have a resident vicar; or 'squire' until in the 19th century the Halls, of the Swan Brewery in Oxford, created the Barton Abbey estate. An existing house was rebuilt by them and renamed Barton Abbey. Middle Barton is a village between the hamlets of Steeple Barton and Westcote Barton. It developed as a Victorian open village and facilities and services were concentrated there. Middle Barton is not a parish and for most of the people the parish church is St. Mary's at Steeple Barton.
